title: Which is the better way to learn, online training or classroom training? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Personally, I prefer traditional school. Now for those who prefer online school, just hear me out. Online school is great because it’s easier to work at your own pace, you can sleep in a little, and you can stay home. But it’s just not my preferred way of schooling.  I like being in a classroom environment with a teacher and classmates. I like being able to have a teacher explain and teach lessons in person rather than watching a video lesson. I like being able to socialize with people in my classes and work on group projects together in person. I’m mostly a kinesthetic learner, so I like being able to do things physically and being in an actual school environment just seems to help with my ability to understand things.  I also like being able to spend lunch with friends and actually see other people in person. I hate facetiming or texting people, and I avoid it unless I have no other way of communicating with people. Also, some classes are difficult to do from home or online, and are definitely not the same as doing them in class. Take Phys Ed for example. A lot of the things we do in phys ed are team games, or require equipment, like for weight training. From home, you are very limited on what activities you can do. You can still do some exercises, but you can’t do anything like team sports activities or anything that requires equipment that you wouldn’t generally have at home. So yeah, I prefer traditional school, but online school is still great, it’s just not for me. . ♥️Your daily dose of fake edginess♥️

Every online class is run differently, but in most cases, it is much easier to schedule your classes around the rest of your day when you go to school virtually. Campus-based courses require that you attend class a certain number of times every week, at specific times. That might mean changing your work schedule or having to hire a babysitter. Online classes sometimes require that you attend scheduled meetings in chat rooms, but in many cases, you can work the virtual classes into your schedule whenever you want. This provides flexibility for you to be able to work toward your degree on your own time, at your own pace. Another important factor to consider is how quickly you are hoping to finish your degree. An associate’s degree typically takes about two years to complete, while a bachelor’s degree takes about four. Keep in mind that these time-frames are based on attending courses full time, which usually means taking at least 12 credit hours per semester. For students who work full time or who have other obligations, an online forum allows the flexibility of being able to take on more coursework each semester without the burden of sitting through classes at set times every day. Interaction You do get to interact with other students at both online and offline universities. It’s a common misconception that students who go to school online never talk with other students or their professors. Your social interactions with students and professors depend on your own habits. If you want to have social relationships with others in your program, you’ll have to reach out in the same way as you would if you had just met someone in a classroom. You’ll interact with other students through VoIP, chat rooms, and email, and your professors are available to help you through the material, just as you’d find at a typical campus college. With many online degree programs, you will find that they offer multiple campus locations as well as student centers in order to provide students with access to professors and advisers if they need face-to-face communication. These programs are designed to help set students up for success by ensuring they have access to any people or resources they may need throughout their education. Resources At an online college, the resources you get will be slightly different than the resources that will be available to you at a traditional campus college. Online schools are less expensive, partly because you don’t have to pay for facilities such as gyms, libraries, dining halls, and residence halls. If you want these to be part of your college experience, you may want to consider attending a brick-and-mortar school. Although, attending an online school does not necessarily mean you won’t have access to these amenities; many brick-and-mortar institutions offer online programs and allow those students access to the same resources as traditional students. And many online programs also have campus locations that can offer you similar amenities. Most online colleges also provide access to virtual libraries, and some even have partnerships with local facilities, so you still have access to the tools you need to be a successful student. Both an accredited online college and a traditional campus college will provide you with the education you need to excel in your field. One style of learning is not necessarily better than the other; the key is to pick the type of program that works best for you, your lifestyle, and your schedule. Factors to Consider With an Online Education Accreditation: Accreditation means that the college or university has met all of the necessary requirements to prove academic excellence through their curriculum, faculty, facilities, and overall competency. Accreditation is what makes your degree valid; any learning institution that is not properly accredited is not credible or recognized as a reputable school. When you are researching online programs, this is the most important factor to look into if you want your degree to be accepted by future employers.Cost: Getting the most value for your dollar is important, so shopping around for a program that fits your budget is essential. The upside to online programs, aside from the flexibility they offer, is that generally speaking, they are more affordable than brick-and-mortar institutions. Many even offer convenient payment plans in order to help break up the cost.Available Financial Aid: Even at a lower cost, it can be difficult for some students to afford to pay for college; looking into various forms of financial aid can help alleviate some of that burden. You should check with potential schools to find out if they offer grants, scholarships, loans, work-study programs, or any other forms of aid. A great place to start if you are interested in applying for financial aid is the Free Application for Federal Student Aid.Courses Offered: Not all online schools are created equal; newer programs may not offer the courses or degree plan you need. Before committing to an online school, you want to make sure that they offer what you are looking for. For brick-and-mortar institutions that offer online programs, another option is taking part of your coursework online and part on-campus if the courses are not all offered in a virtual setting.Graduation Rate: This is another important factor that should weigh into your decision. Knowing what percentage of students who graduate from a particular school can tell you many things. This number calculates the total number of degree-seeking students compared to the percentage of those students who graduate. Low graduation and retention rates could be caused by the lack of support a school provides. Be sure to thoroughly research any potential schools to ensure that they have the proper tools, support, and faculty in place in order to help you succeed.

Face-to-face classroom education has been the only way to attend classes for thousands of years. Now, we can take classes online. They are more attractive, convenient, and accessible. That’s why I prefer them over F2F courses. It's true that some types of classes are better face-to-face, at least to some degree. For example, you can’t learn to put out a fire or perform surgery without practice. It obviously depends on the sphere of activity. Here are the reasons why I prefer online to F2F classes: You can study at your own pace. While the instructor sets the deadline for completing the course, i.e., until midterm, you can choose when you study on your own. There are also some topics that are difficult to understand at first. An online course is available 24/7, so you can watch it again from the point where you get stuck and can submit some carefully thought out questions.Learn on the go. Universities post courses on online platforms, and this is the next point of convenience. It makes learning possible anywhere through your device: while commuting, in a cafe, at the university or at home on the couch. You only need an Internet connection.Fewer errors. Some courses include online simulators that allow you to make all your mistakes during the learning process, try out different scenarios (e.g., conduct an in-depth interview with possible answers from potential respondents), and see the consequences of your actions. So, when you start working, you will already have some experience and a clear understanding of the situation.Attractiveness. A person can maintain his or her focus for 20 minutes on average, and then their attention gets scattered. You often don’t listen carefully if the topic isn’t interesting for you. Online classes give you the opportunity to select pieces that you still have to learn and skip those you already know. Moreover, online classes are often attractively designed to keep your attention.Plus, if you want to take some extra training, getting it online will save money. Online courses give you the opportunity to learn from the best professionals and you can select the instructor based on reviews or the educational program. In-person sessions with such an instructor would require much greater effort and resources from the professor's side. So, it will be much more expensive.

IN AN IDEAL WORLD, if you have the money and time, nothing beats to learn something in a brick-and-mortar class from a good instructor. But that’s also the problem, isn’t it? What if you do not have the time or money, if you are in the wrong location and live nowhere near the campus, and if the instructor turns out to be a disaster? That’s when online teaching shines. With online teaching, you usually do not need a lot of money to take the course.You can take the course whenever you want.You can take the course from any location you want.And if you do not like the instructor, you can switch to a different instructor with the click of your mouse.That actually happened to me. I took a number of online Microsoft Excel courses none of which were provided by competent instructors. But the courses were either free or I could get my money back if not satisfied. At the end of this online search, I at last found a course that was given by a dynamite Excel teacher! I couldn’t be happier. I still go back and study different lessons of his course to brush up on my Excel skill set. There is also the issue of a CERTIFICATE of DIPLOMA. Most regular colleges issue diplomas or degrees that are worth something in real life and that’s why they charge you an arm and a leg. But that does NOT mean that they necessarily teach a lot better than online courses. It all depends. The good news is, some employers these days are NOT looking at your diploma but your real-life skills and what you can for them. My son, for example, studied history at college but right now works as a top-notch web developer; something he was always good at. So lack of a diploma may not always be the disadvantage that you might think it is. (LET ME ADD THIS TOO — there ARE online course providers that actually issue CERTIFICATES OF COMPLETION or “diplomas” of various sorts including some of the best known universities in the United States. You may check out UDACITY and COURSERA for example. And for a general list of certificate/diploma providers for technical writing programs in the United States, I recommend my comprehensive list Certificate Programs in Technical Writing & Technical Communication | Technical Communication Center)

Though I accept that an being in a classroom is “better” in several ways than online, there are several advantages to online learning: Online courses allow you to study at your own pace and schedule. This is of particular importance to adult learners. I have done a number of courses on edX by doing my lessons before work or on weekends. Single parents and working adults would have access to education in cases where they might of been able to afford school, but just didn’t have the time or circumstances.It is far less expensive to deliver. If all state universities had to have 100% of all classroom work online, it would move us closer to having universal education without the sword-fights over funding. It would even benefit in resident students, as if they miss a few classes due to the flu, they would have an easy way to make up the difference.It eliminates the scheduling issues that some students have, when they need a class but it’s “full,” or on the opposite end, it does not run due to too few students signing up (I had that occur to me, as I was a part-time student going to night school. Some courses ran only once a year.) One aspect it eliminates is the EEOC issues. Colleges now have to limit admissions by being selective. In many cases they use criteria other than test scores in an attempt to “level” the playing field. The point here is with being online, not being able to attend the classroom version is “not the end of the world” if you don't get accepted. If your test scores qualified you to attend, then you get to attend one way or another. Note I consider “distance learning” were you watch & listen to classroom instruction in real-time to be pretty much “campus schooling” last: I realize some programs have lab requirements. That would have to be worked out, but I see it as doable. However, if we free up some resources with many student opting for online options, even by choice due to the convenience factor, then the classes that absolutely require attendance would benefit. Edit: One extra point to those who think online is a step down from a classroom, just remember that many first-year students are taught in this format:  I’m not sure how those people in the back row benefit anymore than someone watching via a webcam, or watching even a week later.

All of this means that students, from working professionals to recent high school graduates, find many reasons to take all or some of their courses online. The following list includes 10 advantages to online learning.  Variety of programs and courses: From traditional four-year universities to completely online career colleges, higher education today offers a variety of options for students. This means that no matter what students study, from nursing to neuroscience, they can find the courses or programs they need online. Students can also earn every academic degree online, from a career certificate to a doctorate.Lower total costs: Online programs prove a more affordable option than traditional colleges. Though not all online degrees offer less expensive net tuition prices than traditional colleges, associated expenses almost always cost less. For example, there are no commuting costs, and sometimes required course materials, such as textbooks, are available online at no cost. In addition, many colleges and universities accept credits earned via free massive open online courses (MOOCs), the most recent advance in online education. These free online courses can help students fulfill general education requirements.More comfortable learning environment: Commercials that feature online students studying in their pajamas only skims the surface of one of the benefits of online education: no physical class sessions. Students listen to lectures and complete assignments sent to them electronically, with no need to fight traffic, leave work early for class, or miss important family time.Convenience and flexibility: Online courses give students the opportunity to plan study time around the rest of their day, instead of the other way around. Students can study and work at their convenience. Course material is always accessible online, making special library trips unnecessary. All of these benefits help students balance work and family commitments with their education.More interaction and greater ability to concentrate: While contradictory evidence about the rate of online student participation versus participation in traditional courses exists, one thing remains certain: Online courses offer shy or more reticent students the opportunity to participate in class discussions more easily than face-to-face class sessions. Some students even report better concentration in online classes due to the lack of classroom activity.Career advancement: Students can take online courses and even complete entire degrees while working, while in-between jobs, or while taking time to raise a family. This academic work will explain any discontinuity or gaps in a resume as well. Also, earning a degree can show ambitiousness to prospective employers and a desire to remain informed and prepared for new challenges.Continue in your profession: Even if someone wants to complete a degree, it may not mean they want to leave their current job. For most students today, increasing college costs mandate that some students continue working while in school. The previously mentioned flexibility of online programs enable students to keep working while also pursuing academic credentials.Avoid commuting: During snowstorms and thunderstorms, colleges may cancel classes to avoid putting commuting students at risk of dangerous driving conditions. Rather than miss important class sessions, students in online courses can always “attend” by participating in discussion boards or chat sessions, turning in their work on time, and watching lectures or reading materials. Many students also find substantial savings on fuel costs with no commute for classes.Improve your technical skills: Even the most basic online course requires the development of new computer skills, as students learn to navigate different learning management systems (LMS) and programs. The participation skills students learn within their online courses translate to many professions, including creating and sharing documents, incorporating audio/video materials into assignments, completing online training sessions, etc. Some schools even offer students free laptops or iPads.Transfer credits: For college students who want to attend summer classes, but live too far from their colleges and/or work summer jobs, taking online classes from an accredited college and transferring the credits to their primary college can be beneficial. Students can earn college credit while still enjoying their summer vacation or fulfilling the responsibilities of their seasonal employment. Similarly, if a college or university does not offer enough open sections of a required course, students can take the course online at another college and transfer the credits.

Two decades or so ago, opinions like these were common: “How can people buy things online? You can never match the experience of shopping in stores!” “Is it safe to bank online? Nothing can ever match the high street banking experience!” “Where can you get good study/reference materials? A library, any day!” You get the idea. Online coaching is great. Once you overcome the resistance to change (which BTW is strong, given that learning as we know it in schools and colleges is usually in classrooms), you will realize that online learning is a convenience that you cannot allow yourself to miss. The best part of online learning is that it gives you the chance to attend classes by the best teachers. You no longer need to fret that your city or coaching center does not have that amazing prof you had heard about! In some answers to this question, the respondents have said that with online coaching, you need a lot more sincerity and commitment to learn as compared to offline. I disagree. If you aren't motivated enough, attending a class isn't going to make you more so. :)  If you are motivated enough, online coaching won't hold you back. In fact, you can learn anytime you please, at the pace you want. You can even choose the topic for the day's class based on what you are in the mood to learn. As to participating in class and getting doubts cleared, we tend to view traditional classrooms through rose-tinted glasses when thinking of these things. A good teacher paces himself to address the slightly-below average student in a class. You are forced to go with this flow whether you understand the concept in the first minute or remain clueless even after the class is over. And a vast majority of students hesitate to ask doubts that seem "silly". With online coaching, you can rewind the class as many times as you like and raise doubts without worrying about how it make you look in front of classmates! This is not to say all classroom learning is bad—just that there are two sides to the same coin! Online coaching is also priced way lower than classroom coaching. Of course, not all online coaching is created equal. A good teacher is a good teacher, whether he/she teaches online or in a class! The converse too is true. So, you need to choose the online course carefully. So, read reviews of the course online. Also, go with the courses that allow you to sample a part of the actual course before you buy. Nothing like first-hand experience to help you make up your mind! All the best!

I’m one person who had benefited from both traditional classes and online classes at various stages of my academic life. I’ll explain my preference among these at various stages of life with reasons and my gains. Is online better than traditional classes? From knowledge transfer perspective, it is a concrete ‘yes’. But, will I suggest online classes for schools and undergraduate courses? A big ‘No’. Under the present situation of pandemic when schools and colleges are shifting to online mode at least on a temporary basis, this question is of prime value! As a school child, many of us won’t have clear aims in life and it would be very difficult to develop interest in studies without an aim! Then how did you manage to develop interest during your childhood? I’ll point out few that helped in my case: 1. I used to like science period just because my teacher used to take us out and teach us by showing small experiments in the open. 2. I liked Malayalam period for the stories my teacher used to tell us while teaching. 3. There was an issue in saying ‘no’ to a teacher whom I got personally attached with. So I had to do home works or tasks given by that teacher without any excuses. 4. Good vibes of receiving appreciation in front of the class on good performances and the fear of insult on bad performances used to provide some extra fuel. These are some indirect ways in which we develop the habit of learning and these things happen better in traditional schooling than online classes. This is just one part of the gains of traditional education during school days. I’ll show the other part now: You may have good subject knowledge and ideas to develop new stuffs, but you will also need to convey your ideas and developments to the world so as to succeed. You will need confidence, presentation skills and interpersonal skills. Traditional schools help in this by providing opportunities to take part in cultural events and literary events from very young age. Every time you step onto the stage, you’ll come back with a bag full of confidence and positivity. I remember my teachers dedicating good amount of their time in preparing us for different events at school. During those seasons, our English teacher used to turn to a Drama teacher, Malayalam teacher to a Dance teacher and so on.  One moment from my school days that I’ll always remember is of my teacher interrupting me in the middle of examination at school during my 12th std and taking me to the designated centre in our district for registering my performance in district level arts fest and completing procedures for participating in state level fest. Online classes that focus just on improving subject knowledge won’t even think of something like that, especially in 12th std. Can you guess what the item was? Essay writing English! Today ,when I look back, I realise that those were the stepping stones because of which I’m even writing this! I will anyway write board exam and once I do well there, no one will ask me about my score in mid-terms. But I would never have had the experience of fest had I missed it there. Then comes sports. Back then, I was fat and short, and my chances of winning a running race or long jump on sports day were meagre (you can say zero). Still, the appreciation that I got from school somehow made me believe that I had good chances of winning and I used to hopefully participate in not just one, but 4-5 events one after the other. No one ever discouraged me saying that there is no point in my running! Once, my teachers had even kept me in relay team seeing my excitement. That is the only trophy in running competition that I got in my school life. (for 3rd place because there were only 3 relay teams). I was anyway not a top contender, but I used to stay so excited that I would take just a bite on food so as to satisfy my mom and hurry up to sports ground. As expected, at the end of the day I would end up winning no event but totally exhausted as if I’ve performed so much! Many years forward, today, I find the same enthusiasm when I attend gym or play games and I get good results this time. Now I find running so easy and I do better than most others. The initial ignition created by traditional schooling helped me!  Coming to college life, this is an undergraduate course and you need to gain decent subject knowledge. Why do I still suggest traditional college life over online classes? Here is the reason - Before college, you are controlled in some way by one person or the other. After college, you will get into situations where you can’t afford to experiment. It’s the college where you get to experiment and learn life skills! Here you get situations to put skills that you gained from school into practice and develop them from real world perspective. My college offered me enough opportunities to participate, plan and organize different events. I got to develop my ideas, create events, do good team work, improve my communication and interpersonal skills, meet many successful personalities and make good use of it!  Now, let’s discuss about the phase of my life where online classes came to my rescue: This was the stage after my college life when I had started working. I developed some genuine interest in gaining subject knowledge and wanted to get master degree from the best possible institute. Now, my only aim is to gain enough knowledge and expertise in Computer Science so as to score as high as possible in GATE and I had no need to develop extra-curricular skills or personality traits from GATE coaching. All that I wanted was to get coached by the best teacher! Here, online class was a clear winner. Pros: 1. I can attend online classes taken by the teacher of my choice – I’ll surely pick the one whom I think is the best! 2. No time wastage in commute, no time wastage in waiting for classes to start. 3. I needed the teacher to be available at my comfort as I have to attend office during office hours. When classes are online, I can watch whenever I’m free as they are recorded. 4. No classroom etiquette to be followed. I can be on my own! 5. Can learn when in mood, can take a nap and get up fresh when sleepy. 6. I can control video speed. I no more need to wait for the teacher. I can choose the fastest possible speed for my comfort and save time. 7. I can re-play any part that I find tough to grasp. In regular class, teacher can’t repeat for every single student. 8. No disturbance. I can sit and watch lectures in a peaceful environment with no disturbance at all. Cons: Just one – instant doubt clearance is not possible as videos are recorded. I think this one factor is worth compromising given that you have enough pros! This time, classes were 100% dedicated on providing me subject knowledge and I got well in sync with it. I put in some decent efforts and ended up being All India 39th rank holder.  Conclusion – Online class is clear winner coming to transfer of subject knowledge given that the student is self-motivated and doesn’t need lab or other facilities to proceed. I will surely recommend online classes if you are in this solely for gaining subject knowledge. Coming to schools and undergraduates, traditional classes will always be my pick as compromising a bit in knowledge gain is worth as you’ll get to learn enough life skills!

Your question is very broad. For most students I would say no. That’s especially true for the youngest students. However, for some students it can be better. And with COVID-19 numbers what they are in some areas, it is better than spreading the virus in schools. Some things really are the lesser of evils. How effective online learning is depends in part on the age and development of the student. Young kids do not learn best online. There is no such thing as a “robust” kindergarten curriculum online. Human connection is vital, either with a teacher or parent. There are quality online courses for older students, high school and college, but I don’t think anything replaces good in person discussion and debate. Being online is fine, but you never know when mom is sitting beside her child prompting him. As students get older, they need to learn to function in a group and independently. A lot of good can be said for learning independently. But it isn’t always better than learning with others. We are still social beings. I’ve taken online college courses, and in general I would prefer in person course work. It’s harder to motivate online, there’s no human connection,. I find it more difficult. But that’s not to say that for some people and for some subjects it doesn’t work. It would not work well for a lab science, but it can work well for a history or English course. So there’s your answer, maybe, sometimes, but not always.

When it comes to learning, both types of learning are equally important whether it is online learning or traditional learning. The end goal here is to get a solid understanding of the topic. There are some students who can learn more effectively with the help of a visual medium rather than a theoretical means of learning. These students love online learning as a wonderful means of learning. Why people are inclined towards Online Learning? As we all are facing the problems caused by COVID-19 which causes schools to shut down the only mode of learning that we can have right now is Online learning. It is the best and most safer option to practice amidst the Corona Virus outbreak. It is a cost-effective and good option that enhances the overall learning experiences of the kids. The best thing about online learning is that all the things which are discussed are well documented on the internet in a dedicated platform and the student can refer to these documents anytime he/she has any type of doubt using the internet. For example, let us assume the teacher has given a lecture on the Binomial theorem and the student has missed that lecture. Then he can access the recorded session of the teacher from the learning platform and learn about the concept easily.  Why Traditional learning is useful? The traditional learning is the oldest form of learning. It is still practiced in most of the school and is considered as the most wonderful way of Student-Teacher interaction on a personal level. With the help of Face-to-Face teaching, the teacher can track the student activities and their behavior more easily. For Example, If a teacher is delivering a lecture on Ohm’s law he notices the child’s body language to judge whether the student is understanding the topic or not. If the student is yawning and talking with friends then the teacher can easily detect this behavior and ask the child to focus. This type of behavior tracking for each individual student is not possible for the teacher. In traditional learning, teachers are aware of the individual students' abilities and learning pace thus they prepare the chapter accordingly so that each person can fully understand the topic. Which one to choose- Online Education Vs Traditional Education? Both of these are wonderful learning options if we combine both of these then we will get an even more effective learning technique in the form of Blended learning which is a combination of both Face-to-Face learning along with online education that will complement each other. Conclusion Thus, Blended learning is the most effective option to choose as a learning model that has the functionalities of both. Thanks for reading my answer! Stay Healthy, Stay Inside!

“Studying online” is a very, very broad term. Studying online could refer to a MOOC, to reading a textbook online, to taking a college course online, to studying one-on-one with a tutor online. Some online options may be better than “regular” classes, whereas others will be worse. Of course, this also depends on the quality of the class as well as the individual learner or student. I can speak on this topic from my own research and experience to do with online tutoring - specifically, one-on-one, face-to-face tutoring in an interactive digital classroom. For a lot of students, this is the solution they need. In a “regular” class, they get divided attention from an instructor who’s attempting to pace a lesson for 30 students who all learn at different speeds and to appeal to the learning styles of 30 unique students, each with their own learning goals and challenges. If the pace and methods of the teacher don’t work for them, the best option is to fill gaps with undivided attention from a professional tutor. Now, you’re probably saying to yourself, “Sure, but why can’t that tutor be a regular in-person tutor?” Fair point. Sure, they could be a regular in-person tutor, but an in-person tutor simply cannot beat the online alternative for the following reasons (these reasons refer to credible online tutoring companies and use Skooli as an example): Online tutors are more affordableOnline tutors are more accessibleOnline tutors are background and criminal record checkedOnline tutors need to have professional qualificationsOnline tutoring sessions are recorded and can be rewatched laterOnline tutoring sessions can be attended from home or on-the-goOnline tutors can be located anywhere; students aren’t restricted to the teaching capabilities of local in-person tutorsIf you need extra help with your academics, try online tutoring with Skooli. Be sure to let our support team know you came from Quora. We love Quora.

Both have their pros and cons. Classroom Learning Pros: Physical student-teacher interaction; it is easier to understand the student’s expressions, concentration, and understanding levels Cons: Unneeded distractions and deliberate class disruptions; if there’s a fest going on, then concentration is shot; a need for commute which means less time for class; not all have the same level of processing complex information so it is difficult to maintain the level of understanding Online Learning Pros: Self-paced; more engaging with new tech and SMART classrooms; affordable with low-cost investment; no need for commute - learn anywhere; transferable knowledge; low distractions and greater concentration; no time wastage Cons: Bandwidth and connectivity issues; requires active internet; low understanding of student’s expressions and problem points; never know who’s actually listening and who’s ditched the class Based on the above, I’d say online learning is a tad better because students can understand the concepts at their own pace without hindering the rest; it is also much more affordable than classroom learning - you’ve got comfortable surroundings, no need to spend on travel, learn anytime, anywhere, and the knowledge is applicable in real-life scenarios - overall bonus points. The cons - bandwidth issues and other technical errors are fixable; as for students ditching, well those who want to learn, they do learn, the rest can be properly motivated by incentives ;) So yeah, online is the way to go. I’d recommend Coursera and Edu4sure as staring points - the platforms are comprehensive, structured, have millions of courses both basic and advanced. Edu4sure also provides 1-on-1 mentoring in doubt sessions and both have comparable price points. Hope this helps you out. Happy learning!

Well, I started my online tuition program 3 years back. I was immensely surprised by the convenience it offered as a tutor and so were my students. It saves a lot of time, as compared to conventional classes. Conventional tuitions or coaching centers are at city centers usually and commuting is a matter of concern for students who stay at remote places.There is a wider set of tutors available online. You can choose among the tutors whom you are comfortable with in terms of quality and level of teaching which suits you. So it’s not as generic as a conventional class, which is meant for a wide range of students from different background.The one to one or group classes (conferencing) have its difference in the individual attention for students. A live discussion forum is the new combined study.In this era of e-learning, online resources should be expoloited to the maximum. Online classes and lectures are in abundance and will replace tuitions and postal coaching completely in the near future.Tests, assignments and evaluation could be done online. There is no loss of report and analysis is simpler. Parents can also access the performance reports online.There are online teaching platforms for school/graduate levels or anyone for that matter, who wants to pick up a hobby or a foreign language. I’ve taught for over 40 years in a program at Southern Methodist University’s engineering school that has both on line and in-class students. My observation is that some students work best with one and some best with the other. My teaching style has adapted to fit both. On line students have some major advantages: time shifting (they can watch lectures at their own convenience) and space shifting (they can be where they are rather than going to a classroom) are two of the biggest. This has helped immensely, for example, with students who are in the military or who work for a company whose facilities are not near a campus. But they must also have more discipline - nobody forces them to pay attention, for example. In class students have advantages as well, such as an easier time asking questions of the professor and communication with others in the classroom. In short, it’s not one size fits all. Note also that not all on line programs are well thought out. Having taught in this mode for over 40 years, I’ve learned to make a lot of important changes to how I do things. A lot of what I see at some on line schools is pretty poor in terms of adapting to the needs of the on line students.

It all depends on your work ethic, schedule, and personal preference. I personally know that I would not function well on online school because I get distracted easily while doing schoolwork (I’m supposed to be studying right now). I prefer the challenge and focus of an actual school. I can also take more challenging classes in school that you can’t take online. I would get very bored and lonely without all the friends I see at school daily. I have a friend, however, who does school online and loves it. She can work at her own pace and participate in theater outside of school that she would have to miss a lot of school for. She also can work during the day, which her employer loves. She can go into school to work whenever she wants if she needs help from a teacher. She prefers this by far, but I do not think I would. Some people work better in front of a computer, and others work better in an actual classroom setting. Make sure you take your work ethic into consideration when making this decision. If you want to do other things during the day, it may be a good option. You can always do a year of online school and go back to public school if you don't like schooling online or vice versa. Best of luck in your decision!

I’d say it depends on your goals. Both online courses and university courses can provide awesome instruction in just about any field. If you want to learn something quickly and cheaply, online is a great bet. If you want solid credentials and connections with professors and peers, you’re better off with an actual university. You can make connections online too, but there’s something to be said for getting to know people in person. I’ve done a mix of both. I got a B.A. in English Literature from the University of British Columbia, which was awesome, because I read a bunch of amazing books I never would have read otherwise, and I learned a whole new way of thinking. I got a Master’s in Journalism from Carleton University, which gave me a lot of hands-on, practical training and difficult but valuable feedback on my work. I also made some great friends there. The combination of those two degrees eventually led me into a solid career (which I later abandoned to write full-time) as a consultant for advertising agencies. The not-so-awesome part was the $40,000 debt I walked away with. Since then, I’ve taken online courses in writing and business, and learned a ton of useful stuff for only a few hundred bucks. I don’t regret having earned my degrees, though. Some jobs demand university credentials and other ones don’t, so I’d suggest looking into the requirements for what you want to do.

official post as Online education vs Offline education Which is the better option? Online education vs Offline education Which is the better option?  online class  The Corona epidemic has forced us to embrace online education. Over the last few months, we have become acquainted with many different types of technology that we never even dreamed of. Due to the proliferation of the Internet, we used to use a lot of technology for the purpose of education, but now that schools have been completely closed for a long time, we have to raise virtual classes from school to university level. We have been involved with classroom education for decades, so it is often natural to compare the two methods. Right? While both methods have their strengths, they also have their weaknesses. So let’s understand a little bit about both methods. Distance: Does not matter  Distance Does not matter The biggest question in offline education is to be present on the spot. At the school level, this question may not come up but at the university level this type, of course, comes up when certain types of courses are being conducted in certain universities. There are many problems in moving from one place to another then there can be an economic problem and also a social problem. And perhaps the strongest aspect of online education is that the question of distance is now a thing of the past. Sitting anywhere, a person can connect himself to the classroom with a single link. The only condition is that there should be an internet connection. Read also - Expectations form the parents while online education Study on your time.  study on your time We are all so badly arranged in the frame of 8 hours that we know that time has been accepted by God. Getting into the habit of working with a timetable is not possible for everyone. And you don't need to want to study only from 9 to 12 in the morning. When it comes to learning, school is probably over. While in online education a student can study at that time. It is not bound by any kind of time constraint. One can walk in one's own time instead of walking with time. Tools limitations?  tools When teaching in a classroom, only the four walls of the classroom remain the limit. Rarely does a teacher try to get out of those walls? You can teach students through textbooks and maps. While online classes provide you with more than one tool. From animation videos to PowerPoint presentations, a great blog can be shared that allows students to learn from quality references. Time to react  quick reaction There is a kind of eye-contact between the teacher and the students when the student is in the classroom so that the teacher understands what is being taught in the classroom from the reaction of the students whereas in online learning the teacher rarely pays attention. Can give whether the student knows what is being explained or not. Online platforms often have a polling facility that allows them to answer immediately as they have to answer in hundreds of calculations so that the student does not know whether he understands it or not. Recording lectures facility This is one of the limitations of offline lectures. Once a chapter has been explained by the teacher, then again the same lectures, if one has to organize, a lot of limitations arise. Even online platforms facilitate the recording of lectures. Due to which if a person is absent due to circumstances or if a person finds the subject matter of the lectures difficult, then that person can understand it again. Read about - What is new normal? Limitations on extracurricular activities  Extra activities The biggest advantage of classroom education is that it emphasizes extracurricular activities as well as learning so that students can develop other skills as well, while the online system places great limits on extracurricular activities. Which prevents students from developing other skills along with learning. Which is the biggest drop back of online learning. Development of group spirit  group activity Since online education is individual, most young children do not develop a sense of community. Being in a group is also an art. From which a lot can be learned but only small children studying on-screen cannot learn this art which sometimes makes them feel like they are missing a lot in life. Network Issues  Network issues In the same way that offline education is related to the classroom, the network is a basic condition for online education. In developing countries, online education is possible for people living in cities when network facilities have not reached every citizen but efforts are being made to make it not yet possible for people living in rural areas but this is not an easy task. Yes, data has become very cheap in India but has not yet become ubiquitous. Thus, on both sides, there are advantages and disadvantages, but in the current situation, online education is the only way to prevent the transition to corona. This is a broad question without a simple answer. The quick answer it that they can be better but are not always, if ever. It depends on many factors. I assume that by “online classes” you mean synchronous events done through what is called a virtual classroom like Adobe Connect or Citrix GoToMeeting/Webinar as opposed to asynchronous eLearning that is self-directed online learning done at any time that is convenient for the learner. Synchronous classes have an advantage that learners don’t have to travel to a specific location to attend a class. Other than that, the success of an online class is dependent completely on the participants. If the instructor just lectures with PowerPoint slides, they are no better than “regular” classes. If the instructor makes the presentation interactive by asking questions and using discussion, they can be very good but little different from a “regular” class other than the fact that students do not get to interact face-to-face. Another negative factor for online classes is that it is easier for the learner to get distracted by other things like phone messages and mind wandering. Online learners need to be very self-motivated.

As an educator, I believe that in person school is much better than online. In our current world, there is a lot of debate over this. While online schooling might be better in slowing down the transmission rate of COVID-19, I do not believe that students are learning and engaging as much as they would in the classroom. My nephew had to start his first year of school online. He had never stepped foot inside a traditional classroom before. During his zoom meetings, he zones out on the screen. He doesn’t seem to be doing very well with online schooling. High school students may adapt better to online school because they are older and can ultimately do most of their work on their own. This is not the case for primary school students. In the end, each child is different. Every child learns in their own way. Some children may excel with online school, while others will not do well at all.

Online education is actually available in multiple forms and easily mistaken as less helpful very often . But it is extremely useful if used smartly. Let me get to some basic categories of online education - 1- Recorded videos 2- Classroom recordings 3- Personalised Videos The 1st one among the list is the most common . Every second person associated with teaching sector is doing the same thing , many have done a great work though . Basically a person sets up a camera , imagines a scene where he has few students sitting in front of him and then he delivers the lecture on board . Simple , yet ineffective and boring . Not of great help to student also. The 2nd one is a bit organised , as few institutions or startups manage to install nice cameras in 'real' classrooms of some famous teachers in kota and get their classes recorded . You see only the teacher writing on board on your screen , but the teacher is actually involved in a class with 40–50 students . This is a bit better than the previous case as the teacher is more dynamic and energetic in this model . Now the third and the best one . Personalised session, means you learnt or get taught precisely according to your needs . For eg you have studied a chapter at school or your coaching , but a small part of it is still not understood well , few doubts are left , few more examples are reqd etc etc . Now its only the 10–15% of the chater that you actually require , but if you go to previous 2 cases , it means you have study the whole chapter , get bored up and wait for your part to come . But in personalised session , you and your teacher are actually on a live 1-to-1 video call with his screen shared with you . Ask whatever you want to study or learn , in a precise time , with specific notes and questions . This model is extremely useful and effective as compared with any mode of learning , even with a potential to replace the traditional coaching models also . Thanks for reading so long . Is online education more effective than traditional learning? Online “education” still consists of a single teacher, holding back 29 students so that number 30 can survive. A one-time-produced education about nothing but reality, led by teaching the student How to Think, is the kind of phenomenon that would end teacher’s salaries, retirement, and anything proud about having been a teacher. First step to consider is that not one of those teachers who have taught us for centuries, have ever received any grades that are reflected in their GPA’s that were called; Thinking, Thought, nor How to Think. 30 years ago we had everything for interactive education. However, imagine this? We left interactive education to the US Department of Education in charge of the concept, and they swept it under the rug, because it would cost all the teacher of the analog-teaching world their jobs, retirement, and all those red-apple benefits.

Is the goal to get a degree? Get a job? Get a promotion? Save money? How you answer these questions will help you choose the right path. Online classes can offer exceptional flexibility, value, and even a high-quality learning experience with great opportunities to build a strong network. They require you to be disciplined and self-directed. You have to take initiative to get the most out of such an experience. Consider that many “actual Universities” offer fully online programs and individual courses. Some reasons to enroll in an on-campus experience instead: The institutions near you, or that you would be willing to move for, have a strong reputation in the area you’re looking to learn.The teachers at those institutions are people from whom you want to learn.The students in those classes are people with whom you want to develop a rapport.The other aspects of the University experience (co-curriculars, residential, sports, culture, etc) are important to you.So…what is your goal? What are your values? How do you learn best?

Under three conditions, I’d say. First: you must be a self-directed type. Like to procrastinate? Online probably isn’t for you. Good at scheduling your time even when you don’t have to? You’ll probably do fine. But “I can do the work whenever” is the worst thing ever to say in an online setting, because it equates to work never getting done. Second, it must be a good program. With profitability growing, a lot of online programs appeared that basically took classroom components such as PowerPoints and lecture notes and tossed them online. Doesn’t work that way, though. Each different mode of education deserves its own considerations. An online class and a classroom class can teach the exact same objectives, but they cannot be taught the same way. Third, you must be an effective writer. Most online classes require “forum” interaction between students — heck, that’s actually one of the things that works well only online, going back to my second point — but in those cases there are neither verbal nor facial cues, so you have to be able to express yourself precisely and concisely.

It's far better to go to a real university. Per the SOLO taxonomy, online courses tend to top out at multistructural complexity. A good U should get you into the extended abstract. This is due to technology limitations that will persist until moderately strong AI is available in online course software. That said, a bad U course might also leave things wanting at multistructural and your wallet empty. Thus the saying MOOCs haven't made education much better, rather they've made it more difficult to charge for bad education. There's no doubt you can learn a great deal, fill in a lot of gaps and raise your level of learning via self-paced learning with determination, flexibility and curiousity, i.e. seek out mentors, read books, ask yourself the complex questions, etc. But not many people have the energy or motivation to do so.

This depends on the kind of “traditional class” you refer to. If it’s a large lecture class with no questions, an online class can be just as (in)effective as a F2F lecture. Lectures are little better than well-written texts. Some rare professors can make large lectures an exciting experience—not many do. AND let’s take into account that people learn in different “preferred” channels. Some people prefer to hear things to reading or “seeing” them. Some people cannot sit and prefer to be active while learning. Brain chemistry also filters in here. A large lecture for a person with ADHD is not the best way to “learn.” My experience and career has been based on case method classes which include the following: Selection of cases that present real, (not made up) business problems and end with a decision dilemma (not description cases).Selection of accompanying technical notes or chapters that give students some frameworks for analysis.Writing a syllabus that charts a path through related business problems.Students with some work experience who read and analyze the materials in advance.Students who meet in learning teams to make sure everyone is as far as they can go with the case given different backgrounds and experiences.90 minute classes.Rooms with semi-circular seating so everyone can see and listen to everyone.Rooms with multi-media channels—internet, chalkboards, flip charts, projectors, overhead cameras, audio systems.Instructors who cold call on students (not just volunteers) so everyone has a chance to speak and express their opinions.Instructors who are highly skilled at asking good questions that stimulate thought for everyone.Discussions in which the students talk more than the instructor.Discussions in which what the students say is graded daily by the instructor after class.Discussions that include intense role plays—only when implied by student comments.Discussions in which the instructor is facilitating learning and going at the envelope of the STUDENTS’ understanding not the instructor’s.Discussions characterized by high energy, humor, deep insight, working at the edge of students’ understanding, no interruptions (coming in late, going to the restroom, AV faux pas, etc.) multi-media segments seamlessly intermixed, and complete and intense focus on the “magic bubble” of collective insight in the room.Summaries driven by the students’ insights and only the gaps filled in by the instructor.THAT’s a “traditional class” to me. I tried to get all of that every class, every course. I’ve taught on-line classes. Invariably they were a miserably poor approximation of what happens in the class outlined above. People on commuter trains, in coffee shops, watching tv etc. in the on-line classes, no facial or body language, connectivity issues, synchronous versus asynchronous structures, and on and on. ONLINE courses are a reasonable approximation of a lecture class. LECTURE classes are a very poor substitute for a well-done F2F CASE METHOD class. There’s little comparison. The ASSUMPTION of the question above is that most students have experienced LECTURES as the typical “traditional” class. That is a travesty of educational institutions and instructors who don’t understand the basics of adult learning. See Teaching Management.

However, one thing is for certain as in all cases which is that if there is a willingness to learn by the student they will always find a way to learn.

The answer to this question is blurring over time. As Janera states, it depends on many factors. In-person classes allow for rich interaction and can result in an enhanced learning environment. Physical textbooks. Always, or whenever possible. I have nothing against doing so, but some people who grew up with computers prefer computers; I didn’t, and although I can look up facts here and there on my desktop, it’s disorienting jumping from tab to tab, from a page to a hyperlinked page, copy-pasting stuff to various files, etc., is weird. And there is that fatigue(?) from staring at that glaring white screen.

I tried some online courses to get students to learn in a different way and at their own pace. It didn’t end well. The good students finished in a week The students that didn’t want to learn tried to take a month. They needed much more hands on help to even halfway stay on task. The good students pursued more online training. The others didn’t. I wound up with two totally different levels of competence. I had to develop lessons and two different grading systems. The more online training I did the more the gap widened.

Most of us have grown up listening to our professors droning on in a classroom, during a seemingly unending lecture. Using mobile phones in classrooms were strictly forbidden. But now educational institutes are increasingly using mobile devices for teaching purposes. In the last decade we have seen a dramatic change in the training pattern. Mobile devices have become a part of training and teaching methods. So what is better, the age old classroom learning or the modern eLearning? Let’s have a look at a couple of advantages and disadvantages of both teaching methods. Advantages of Classroom learning Human interaction We, as humans, crave for human interaction. In a traditional classroom training model, there’s a physical trainer present, who imparts knowledge. A living breathing mentor obviously has an upper hand over a machine. Dialogue There are more opportunities to ask questions and get your doubts clarified. Sometimes, one question leads to another and it might eventually lead to a whole new topic. The teacher can tell us about things that are not limited to the course contents. Disadvantages of Classroom learning Reluctance to ask questions We do know that some students are timid and might shy away from asking questions in front of an entire classroom. Their doubts would remain unanswered, unless brought up by another student. Individual attention A teacher cannot pay attention to every student in the classroom. And we all have taken advantage of this in some way or the other- hiding behind someone to avoid answering a question, doodling on the last page, or taking a nice 30 minute nap. Advantages of eLearning Flexible Students don’t have to carry loads of books everyday. One digital device is enough, it could either be a smartphone, tablet, PC or laptop. eLearning content can be accessed anywhere and anytime. Students can access the study materials whenever they want, as per their convenience. Some eLearning platforms also offer an offline option which doesn't require internet connection to access the content. Interactive No longer do the students have to just sit and listen to someone constantly talking. They can actually be more proactive in their training program. The online content can be embedded with external links for more information, videos, audio etc to make the learning process more engaging and interactive. 3D simulations, interactive games and gamifications make the training program more challenging, providing students with an opportunity to interact with their peers, coordinate and solve problems. With quizzes and interactive assessments, the trainer can evaluate the progress of every student. Introducing eLearning in classrooms makes the learning process more interactive and helps in knowledge retention. Disadvantages of eLearning Unmotivated learners Some students might not feel motivated enough to peruse the online content without an actual classroom environment. They could get distracted and might end up just mindlessly staring at the screen. This unenthusiastic behaviour would lead to wastage of time. One really needs to be self-disciplined in order to continue with eLearning. Technical issues Your device must be compatible with the training module. Some online content work only on certain kind of devices. Also, some online training can be accessed only with an internet connection. Slow or broken connection can hamper the learning process, making the learner frustrated.

When is online education better than classroom education? That’s easy: when the online education is viable and the classroom education is not. I’m never going to accept that an online program is superior (ceteris paribus), but people aren’t necessarily available at the time and place that the requisite coursework is offered. At that point, an online education is a substitute. There are concerns about how much material you capture absent certain classroom experiences (e.g., discussion, labs, etc.) and face-to-face interaction with your professors, but the real issue is that online degree completion rate is very low for competitive programs.

Almost always, classroom education is better. Just because someone CAN do something all online, does not mean he SHOULD. In general, the model of education works: Read and prepare before class.Have a teacher with an experienced lecturer who can facilitate presentation.Get some practice in class, and even some independent, real world production.Go home and do homework to practice.Yes, with online learning, Coursera, etc. there are many ways to get information at your fingertips. But, should a person? No, especially not if there is a community and team of learners dedicated to that.

One prediction that you see a lot, a completely computerized education system probably will not occur. After more than 30 to 40% of class time is spent on computers, learning seems to decline. So, there will still be teachers and classrooms, although most homework will be done on computers, not on paper. Computer based instruction and e-learning is cheaper to provide for large quantities of people. However, that form of learning is often relegated to basic information (data requiring memorization) and compliance training. Even when being trained to use a computer system, people learn faster and retain more when there is a live teacher in the room with them providing instructions. In the age of rapid change, a live teacher can update material much faster than computer based instruction can be reprogrammed. Finally, students often learn more from other students than instructors and that tends not to occur with on-line education.

Both have their merits. I will start with online.When you are online, there is an abundance of information at your fingertips, and it can be accessed day or night. You can go to one of billions of webpages to find your information, and if there isn't enough you can go to a different page. However, if you get stuck then there is no one to help you. It also requires a lot of focus to not get distracted by other websites, and you run the risk of getting false information. In a classroom you have the advantage of having people around you to help you, and to keep you focused, but it is not available at all times, and can cost you money.  There is also a limited amount of information in a textbook. I would suggest using both methods to learn, as they each have their pros and cons.

Though we cannot totally discount the importance of traditional classroom learning yet, it is a fact that online learning has a major role to play in today’s tech-driven world. Online learning should be seen as a supplement to face-to-face learning, not a replacement. Blended learning is an example where these two methods of learning come together to offer a more comprehensive and enriching learning & development experience. With many advanced learning management systems (LMSs) available at present, deploying eLearning and online employment training is a lot easier than ever before. To give a specific example, ProProfs Training Maker is a cloud-based learning management system that you can use to unlock all the benefits of a hosted software application. It comes with the following features: Custom course creationEducational path planningReal-time trackingReports & AnalyticsCertificationAll this makes this tool highly valuable. It is a simple yet functional platform that can help optimize and meet all your online training needs. By providing both pre and post-training support, the tool makes distance learning or workforce training such as onboarding a breeze. One of the best parts of such training software is their time and space-defying nature in that both instructors and course attendees can access them anytime, anywhere using multiple devices. The moment you embrace such a versatile, robust, and smart tool, you would never look at online learning with the same eyes again.

Online classes are a unidirectional way of teaching considering students having doubts won’t be satisfied in their clarification as compared to that of a classroom,and obviously there are the concerns of internet stability which causes disturbances on both the sides, the teacher and the student. 1. ELearning does help save costs. Moreover, it helps both educational institutions and students do so. Colleges don’t have to provide students with space for learning and with some additional materials for their education. Students don’t have to travel somewhere to build new skills and gain new knowledge. While e-learning still requires teachers to record their lectures and create courses, these learning materials can be used for a long time and easily changed when the need comes. Therefore, colleges save money on instructors and professors too. 2. ELearning does make the education more available. For some students coming to another country to study something is impossible, especially if they want only to study a certain course instead of receiving a degree. E-learning simplifies the process greatly, allowing students from all over the world to complete courses created by world’s best universities. This benefits native students too, allowing them to communicate and study along with people coming from different cultures. Sure, there are colleges that offer multicultural experience too, but they aren’t as diverse as the online learning institutions. 3. ELearning does make students more mobile. E-learning allows students to study from any place where they have a stable internet access. It also allows them to study at any time they find comfortable. All this not only makes the learning process easier for people living in different time zones but also allows the students to combine online education with work or getting a college degree. Moreover, this also allows students to organize their time more effectively. For example, you can learn something on your way home in a bus or during your gym training. This means that even the busiest students could learn properly. For more advantages check this blog post Advantages and Disadvantages of E-Learning Technologies for Students

I like in person classes cause if you have study hall or study skills you can do your assignments that you haven’t finished yet and have no homework when you come home and you don’t have your parents getting involved in your work by helping you when you don’t ask for it. Limited availability of different teachers for each subject under one roof & for all classes 3. Limited availability of quality tuition centers for offline tuition. 4. Uncertainty about credibility of available offline teachers or tuition centers 5. High demand but poor supply of quality teachers makes offline home tuition more expensive. 6. Travel time consumed & travel cost incurred during commuting by student or teacher for offline learning or tutoring further increases tuition charges for the student & makes it less economical for the teacher. 7. Wastage of significant amount of time in tiring traffic in metro cities is a problem both for the tutor as well as for the student. 8. Air Pollution in Cities discourages parents, students & teachers for commuting. 9. Safety & security of student especially the safety of girl child is an issue of most concern for the parent during offline tuition process at home or at offline tuition center. 10. Lack of individual attention in offline tuition centre classes. 11. Ease & Convenience in offline home tuition is lesser than online tuition. EASE, CONVENIENCE & ACCESSIBILITY to a big pool of duly screened, properly tested, thoroughly trained, experienced & quality teachers from across India & abroad 2. Better Presentation & Lecture Delivery Automatic class recording Travel time and cost saved. No tiring traffic congestion Variety in Courses All subjects under one roof Safety & Security. However, It applies to 1 to 1 classes. Online group classes have disadvantages than offline group Classes. For exampleOnline Classes by Schools and Coaching Institutes still suffer from one size fits all approach. Due to covid-19, schools and coaching institutes switched over from offline to online classes in order to survive their business but did not update themselves nor did anything to get rid off the same old method of teaching wherein same size fits all approach is still followed. It has further made learning an uncomfortable experience for students as online group classes have added more problems for students such as reduced interaction between student and teacher; audio interruptions due to poor networks, unavailability of devices etc. Personalized 1 to 1 teaching is the key ensure to effective learning in the current online education scenario which suddenly enforced online group classes on teachers who were never trained for taking online classes. The result is that parents have started complaining to schools as parents are monitoring their kid's classes and happen to see various lacuna in online classes ranging from methods of teaching, quality of teaching, interaction of teacher with students, pronunciation, behavior, unnecessary overly assignments & activities, lack of focus on basic concepts etc Schools do not clear basic fundamental concepts, hence, students need to take coaching to clear any competitive exam whether it is engineering, medicine, banking, SSC, CDS, IAS or so on. And because colleges do not cater to education in the way it should be dealt in, that's why 80% Indian engineers, many doctors and most graduates and post graduates do not get jobs in the job market. It's failure of school education system that leads to existence of multi-billion coaching industry in India.

In an online course: you can focus your time only to learn and will have no time to chat with your classmate, you interact with classmate only for peer assessment. In this manner of time efficiency you will have extra available time to learn other lessons;you can simultaneously or sequentially take different online courses of the same topic from different campus/ online courses provider, in this way you can be more knowledgeable than conventional classroom;you can fast forward the lesson for things you already understood well and finish the lesson faster;you can finish more than 10 online courses within 5 months.you can view the subtitle, so you will know exactly what the teacher has to say. My opinion will depend on the stage of study. Primary & Secondary Education ( Elementary / Middle School /High School) : Offline. No online system can really match the schooling system. It may be able to provide all the resources like videos, Assessments etc., but, teachers’ guidance, the hand holding they provide to the students, the confidence they instill cannot be brought in by any software. How much ever AI we bring in, we should not make a kid talk to a computer and take away the emotional development in his/her formative years by taking out the human factor. Diploma / Graduation : It can be a mix as students by this time are matured enough to make the judgement. Post Graduation : Can be online Professional / Career Education : People look for upskilling in this stage and online courses or trainings are better as they provide the flexibility of anytime access, plethora of choices from anywhere in the world etc.

On line classes eliminate class disturbances typically found during the course of a day in in person classes. Samples of routine interruptions are: Late student complains his tardy to class is the first time although he has excessive tarries. Since I am required to assign a detention after 3 tardies, I do so despite his or her grumbling.Fire drill can be false or real. Classes rush outside to be safe while administrators check on the status of the alarm.It is picture day. Effort is taking place to appear the best for the camera. Brushes, makeup, clothing adjustments continue unabated.Announcements regarding an impromptu faculty meeting.A student has lost his or her homework. Student shuffled through notebooks papers, and backpack.Shooter drills upset everybody.A fight breaks out during class change. Discussions in class ensue. Students are summoned as witnesses.All of these issues, plus many more, take place during the course of a day. On line eliminates interruptions to allow for more construction time. On line classes eliminates extracurricular activities and sports team events. Socialization is curtailed. Which is better?

I have become a relaxed mom when I enrolled my son at Ogburn. The highly talented teachers and the individualised curriculum have reduced my burden. My son enjoys learning at his own pace.

I agree with the comments already posted about this, but wish to point out that your question is posed as “either/or”—it’s one or the other. I have found in life that rarely if ever is anything this or that—when it comes to “better” one must always note that it depends on the context and people involved and even then conditions can change. So, it’s not a question of better or worse but often a blend of ideas—for example, many have found on-line AND face to face work well in a blended approach: some classroom meetings, other times on-line with individual help.

For the self-motivated, mature, older, time-and-place-bound student, online study may be a good option. For a traditional-aged residential student, face-to-face classes may be better. Either way, if you need some extra help for a particularly tough part of the course, such as math problems, seek help. If that means coming in physically during a professor’s office hours, that may have to be done.

I would prefer and recommend online learning for multiple reasons - I can learn anywhere of my choice.I can learn any time of my choice.I can easily rewind and revise 1000 times without asking anyone.I can simultaneously google and search other things when in doubt or ask Teacher or Author or other learners of the course for my doubt.Can you see, it’s extremely liberal and I have my own freedom in learning.
