response.answer_text: I admit I am old school. I went to college 1961 through 1965. All classes had a live present professor at the front even when he was a rather large lecture hall class. Modern online or learning does have its place, and may even have its advantages and in some cases. Personally, I think a course taught by a live professor or instructor is better than online because there is the opportunity of interaction between students and instructors. Students can ask questions or make comments and based on these questions or comments, the professor can adjust the pace of his class or even sometimes make adjustments in his lecture as he goes along. The professors we had were excellent scholars in their field with a lot of experience. I believe they were better able to transfer that experience and knowledge to us in the classroom live than online.

Online Class is the only option left to proceed the education in this pandemic. physical interaction can be dangerous and there is no other option left. Although Online Classes is not much beneficial than the actual schooling because there is no physical atmosphere of learning, Student tends to lose the interest of continuing the lecture, it is more technology as many students and groups cannot afford the online class technology.

Not for us. No. My younger son, at 9, was bereft without his classmates, without teachers. He's a sociable wee chap and found online meetings upsetting, and unsatisfying. There were very few online meetings anyway, only about 5, 5 minute meeting in the whole of lockdown. Schooling was haphazard, badly explained and either too easy or too hard. He hated it. My older son, aged 14. Missed the discipline of school - without a teacher there, his work was haphazard. He slacked off, pretending to work and has fallen behind. The school didnt contact me until it was alot of work. We had to work all the holidays to catch up.

Educationists and all those who have a genuine understanding of education would agree that the main form of education has to happen in the face-to-face mode and as a group or social activity. This is necessary to achieve inclusion in education. There are many intangible outcomes in education which can be achieved only through such a mode. Students learn not only from the teacher and books/articles but also from their peers. If we want education to inculcate empathy, democratic behavior, openness and an equitable attitude towards people belong to other caste, religion, race, and gender and so on through education, these cannot be achieved through an education in which the teacher and the student is linked only through the technology.

That depends on many factors. If you’re a young single mother with two babies who only gets time to work on classes when the babies happen to be asleep, an Internet-based course is the only way to go. If however you find yourself watching cat videos for 2 hours for every 10 minutes you put in on your e-class, you might do better to have a distraction-free traditional classroom setting with an instructor trained to keep you on track.

I will always prefer traditional schooling over online. I think schooling is one of the best thing about our education system but I believe online education will make it much much better. So I don't support any one of them but I believe it should be combined and there must be some flexibility.

There were a few times i have chosen taking an online class over an in-class course. In this course, the professor would post the videos online and we would go to the class and write a weekly test. For this course, i did not want to go to the class. For most courses, i would prefer in-class, so i can concentrate more and ask questions immediately without having to write it somewhere and eventually forget without asking.

BrainStation offers Online Live which allows you to learn online but with fellow classmates and a live instructor that you can interact with and learn from. We also offer in-person part-time Certificate and full-time Diploma programs for those that prefer the structure of a classroom and the ability to build a network.

Always. We live with people not machines. School is not just academia and learning facts and figures. IT’s the training of the brain. The brain needs more feedback than just auditory and visual text. We need the social interaction where we see each other in person and read the expressions on the face and body language that goes with it. You can’t get that not the internet or on line courses. The expression of a voice only gives you 30% you need the other 70% to get the full impact and that comes from the facial impressions. WE also especially with the teens and the last 2 generations which means the 20 & 30 yr olds need to learn about communication with real people. Social Manners need to be learned. NOT ignored. You don’t break up with someone on social media. Have the courage to do this in person. We are not cardboard people or an artificial intelligent robot. People have feelings. Man /woman up and start dealing with your emotional hook ups and break ups in person!!

Well, Both has some pros and cons. But I think school classes are better, as students can ask any questions and it becomes easy to understand something when you ask and learn it face to face. I will use the words of the Supreme Court to answer your question. The Supreme Court described the classroom as a Market Place of Ideas. While ideas can be shared online, it seems to me that the sharing of ideas online is not as vibrant, or interactive, as doing so face to face with your fellow students as well as with your professors. The written word is certainly important in studying any subject. However, I found that the side conversations held at the water fountain, in the hallway outside the classroom, or in the break room were often timrs just as important as the classroom lectures and reading assignments. Online learning is absent those opportunities of learning. For my money, classroom learning has my vote.
